00040 #ifndef _world_h

00042 
00043 /**
00044  @mainpage Physgame
00045  The Physgame engine is an abstraction layer between less portable, less user friendly, more sophistciated
00046  libraries and the game you want to make. If we do our jobs right this will save time and effort making and porting
00047  games between a variety of platforms. If you link only against this library, not a single line of your
00048  Standard compliant C++ code should need to change between platforms. At this early stage we are proving the
00049  concept with "Catch!" our first sample game. It Currently runs on Linux and Windows with an Identical
00050  codebase, when we are done with "Catch!" We want it to have one codebase, and downloadable in the Iphone
00051  app store, the Xbox store, on the PS3, on Steam, and in a variety of linux repositories.
00052 
00053  To get the latest news on development checkout: http://gitorious.org/physgame
00054  Or check the webpage http://www.blacktoppstudios.com
00055 
00056  @section Engine Structure
00057   @subpage mainloop1 "Main Loop Flow"
00058 
00059   @ref phys::World "World - It integrates everything"
00060 
00061   @ref phys::CallBackManager "Call Backs - Running Game code from the engine"
00062 
00063   @ref phys::EventManager "Events - Handling messages, event and interupts from the outisde"
00064 
00065   @ref phys::ActorBase "Actors - Items in the world"
00066 
00067  @section Data Types
00068   @ref phys::Vector3
00069 
00070   @ref phys::EventBase
00071 
00072 */
00073

00109 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00110 /// @namespace phys
00111 /// @brief The bulk of the engine components go in this namspace
00112 /// @details This is where imporant classes like World, CallBackManager, and
00113 /// The eventmanager reside. For more detailed usage information please refer
00114 /// to individual class documentation or the @ref index main page.
00115 ///////////////////////////////////////
00116 namespace phys
00117 {
00118     //Forward Declarations
00119     class ActorBase;
00120     class ActorContainerBase;
00121     class GraphicsSettings;
00122     namespace debug {
00123         class InternalDebugDrawer;
00124     }
00125     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00126     /// @class World
00127     /// @headerfile world.h
00128     /// @brief This is the main entry point for the entire library.
00129     /// @details The physworld coordinates and integrates all the underlying subsystems,
00130     /// Currently Ogre3d is used for 3d Graphics, Bullet is used for physics, and
00131     /// SDL is used for user input and window management. Games will need a
00132     /// container for all the playing pieces. It makes sense to tie all of this
00133     /// functionality into one world object.
00134     ///////////////////////////////////////
00135     class World
00136     {
00137         private:
00138             /// @brief Do Not Use this, This should be treated as an internal function, it is \b subject \b to \b change \b without \b warning and could be \b harmful to overall stability if used incorrectly
00139             /// @warning This should be treated as an internal function, it is \b subject \b to \b change \b without \b warning and could be \b harmful to overall stability if used incorrectl
00140             friend void crossplatform::RenderPhysWorld(World *TheWorld);
00141             friend class ActorBase;
00142 
00143             //Physics Items
00144             Vector3 GeographyLowerBounds;
00145             Vector3 GeographyUpperbounds;
00146             unsigned short int  MaxPhysicsProxies;
00147 
00148             btAxisSweep3* BulletBroadphase;
00149             btDefaultCollisionConfiguration* BulletCollisionConfiguration;
00150             btCollisionDispatcher* BulletDispatcher;
00151             btSequentialImpulseConstraintSolver* BulletSolver;
00152             btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* BulletDynamicsWorld;
00153 
00154             //SDL Objects
00155             SDL_Surface *SDLscreen;
00156             bool HasSDLBeenInitialized;
00157 
00158             //Players settings
00159             GraphicsSettings* PlayerSettings;
00160 
00161             //Try to retrieve ogre settinss
00162             void LoadOgreSettings();
00163 
00164             //Manages the windows all the graphics will be drawn to
00165             void CreateRenderWindow();
00166             void DestroyRenderWindow();
00167 
00168             //Used by the constructors
00169             void Construct(const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds, const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds, const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies);
00170             void SanityChecks();
00171             void TestLogger();
00172             template <class T> void OneLogTest(T Data, string DataType,string Message1 = "Logging and Throwing a ", string Message2 = "Logging a ");
00173 
00174             //Settings for Engine Functionality
00175             string WindowName;
00176             Whole TargetFrameLength;
00177             Real PhysicsStepsize;
00178 
00179             //Ogre objects
00180             Ogre::Root* OgreRoot;
00181             Ogre::RenderSystem* OgreRenderSystem;
00182             Ogre::RenderWindow* OgreGameWindow;
00183             Ogre::ResourceGroupManager* OgreResource;
00184             Ogre::Camera* OgreCamera;
00185             Ogre::Viewport* OgreViewport;
00186             Ogre::SceneManager* OgreSceneManager;
00187 
00188             friend class LineGroup;
00189             debug::InternalDebugDrawer* BulletDrawer;
00190         public:
00191

00193         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00194         // Creation and Deletion methods
00195         ///////////////////////////////////////
00196             /// @brief Descriptive constructor
00197             /// @details This constructor allows for an easier way to define the boundaries for items moving about inside the physworld.
00198             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds_ The lower limits for the size of the physics simulation
00199             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds_ The Upper limits for the size of the physics simulation
00200             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies_ This is the amount of Adows (Also called Actors or Proxies) allowed in a physics simulation.
00201             World( const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_, const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_, const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies_=1024);
00202 
00203             /// @brief Default constructor
00204             /// @details This simply performs the same work as the descriptive constructor with some sane, but small, limits. It will give you a world which expands for 100 units from the Origin, and only allows 10 Adows.
00205             World();
00206 
00207             /// @brief Deconstructor
00208             /// @details This Tears down all the items create by the physworld, and safely frees any graphical resources, we will also delete any Objects passed into the
00209             /// Physworld by pointer. We will not delete any pointers we pass out (like from the Events from the Event manager)
00210             ~World();
00211 
00212         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00213         // Logging
00214         ///////////////////////////////////////
00215             /// @brief Runtime Event logging Function
00216             /// @details Be careful with this function, even though it appears to be a template, it does not support every data type. If Physgame is
00217             /// Compiled as a Shared Object, Dynamic Linked Library, or some other kind of stand alone library It will only support data types
00218             /// that are called internally, Currently that list includes: string, char, short int, int, long int, unsigned short int, unsigned int
00219             /// unsigned long int, bool, float, double, long double, wchar_t, size_t, Real, Whole, String, Vector3, RawEvent and MetaCode.
00220             /// If compiled statically it should support any data type which supports output streams.
00221             /// @param Message This is what will be streamed to the log
00222             template <class T> void Log(T Message);
00223 
00224             /// @brief This is the preferred way to throw an exception currently
00225             /// @details This will log the Message, and will throw an exception with the Message included. Currently this supports all the Data
00226             /// type the Log function supports
00227             /// @param Message This will be streamed to the log, then used in a thrown exception.
00228             template <class T> void LogAndThrow(T Message);
00229 
00230         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00231         // Window Management
00232         ///////////////////////////////////////
00233             /// @brief Retrieves the Current Window Title
00234             /// @details This gets the texts that the engine has stored for use in the title bar
00235             /// @return This returns a String Containing the Window Title
00236             std::string GetWindowName();
00237 
00238             /// @brief This can set the the Text in the titlebar
00239             /// @details This changes the text in the bar at the top of the game window in windowed mode. It can be changed at anytime.
00240             /// @param NewName This is the new text to be used in the titlebar.
00241             void SetWindowName(const String &NewName);
00242 
00243         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00244         // Graphics system methods
00245         ///////////////////////////////////////
00246             /// @brief Retrieves the amount of milliseconds we would like each iteration of the Main Loop to be
00247             /// @details In practice hardware performance or timing concerns can cause this goal to be unnaitanable or trivially easy. The main loop with actually
00248             /// pause execution until this amount of time is reach is main loop iteration, However, the mainloop will always skip waiting if hardware is overburdened.
00249             /// @return This returns a Whole with the current Value
00250             Whole GetTargetFrameTime();
00251 
00252             /// @brief This sets a new Target Time
00253             /// @details This sets a new time for each frame. Each iteration of the game loop will take around this long to run, but rarely exactly this long. Setting this value
00254             /// Higher can results in power savings (battery life), but setting it too High can cause choppiness. Settings this value higher can result in smoother gameplay, but
00255             /// set it too high, and system resources could becom completely taxed and power will be wasted.
00256             /// @param NewTargetTime The new length of time, in milliseconds.
00257             /// @warning Setting vary low or very High values could cause unknown errors, This is on our todo list of issues to fix.
00258             void SetTargetFrameTime(const Whole &NewTargetTime);
00259 
00260             /// @brief This sets a new Target Frame Rate
00261             /// @details This sets a new time for each frame. This divides 1000 by the NewFrameRate, drops and floating point amount and uses that amount in an call to
00262             /// World::SetTargetFrameTime. For example a target frame rate of 40 with cause each frame to take 25 milliseconds, and a Framerate of 70 would take 14 ms
00263             /// @param NewFrameRate The new desired frame rate.
00264             /// @warning Setting vary low or very High values could cause unknown errors, This is on our todo list of issues to fix.
00265             void SetTargetFrameRate(const Whole &NewFrameRate);
00266 
00267             /// @brief This Shows an Engine Generated Configuration Screen
00268             /// @details This could look like and could offer just about any option to the user. It is loosely expected to show Graphical Configuration
00269             /// options, like Vsync and Resolution, But it might ask some really silly stuff. I thnk this would be fine for smaller simpler
00270             /// Which have no other way to configure such things, but any sizable project should develop their own way to expose and manage
00271             /// user settings.
00272             bool ShowSystemSettingDialog();
00273 
00274             /// @brief This moves the camera relative to the world
00275             /// @details The parameters really do explain it. This puts the camera at an arbitrary point, pointing at an arbitrary point.
00276             /// @param Position Where should the camera be seated
00277             /// @param LookAt Point the camera such that this poin is centered on the screen
00278             void MoveCamera(const Vector3 &Position, const Vector3 &LookAt);
00279 
00280         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00281         // Graphics system loading methods
00282         ///////////////////////////////////////
00283             /// @brief Adds a location for graphical resources.
00284             /// @details This function will add a location on the disk to find files needed to create and
00285             /// manipulate graphical objects.
00286             /// @param Location The location on the file system the resource can be found.
00287             /// @param Type The kind of file system the location can be found in. @n
00288             /// Options are: filesystem, zip.
00289             /// @param Group The name of the group the resources at this location belong to.
00290             /// @param recursive Whether or not to search sub-directories.
00291             void AddResourceLocation(const String &Location, const String &Type, const String &Group, const bool &recursive=false);
00292 
00293             /// @brief Prepares the resource for use.
00294             /// @details This function can be thought of as a preloader.  This will prepare the defined
00295             /// resource located on the disk for use.
00296             /// @param Name Name of the file/resource to be 'prepared'.
00297             /// @param Type The type of resource that the file is. @n
00298             /// Options are: Font, GpuProgram, HighLevelGpuProgram, Material, Mesh, Skeleton, Texture.
00299             /// @param Group Name of the group the resource belongs to.
00300             void DeclareResource(String Name, String Type, String Group);
00301 
00302             /// @brief Makes a resource group ready to use.
00303             /// @details After adding all of your resources and declaring them as nessessary, this function
00304             /// is the final step.  After calling this function any and all resources within the defined group
00305             /// will be ready to use.  Do not initialize any more groups then you need to however, as that will
00306             /// take up memory and drop performance.
00307             /// @param Name Name of the resource group.
00308             void InitResourceGroup(String Name);
00309 
00310         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00311         // Main Loop and Initialization
00312         ///////////////////////////////////////
00313             /// @brief This creates the game window and starts the game.
00314             /// @param CallMainLoop should the main loop be called
00315             /// @details Prior to this all of the physics and graphical object containers should have been loaded and prepared for use. There should be
00316             /// minimal delay from the time you call this and the game actually begins.
00317             /// This will automatically call the Main Loop unless passed falsed.
00318             void GameInit(const bool &CallMainLoop=true );
00319 
00320             /// @brief This Function house the main loop
00321             /// @details By default this is called from the function World.GameInit() this is were the bulk of the simulation is ran from, see @ref mainloop1
00322             void MainLoop();
00323 
00324             /// @brief Performs all the items that would normally be performed during the game loop
00325             /// @param PreviousFrameTime This is the amount of time that has elapsed since this function was last called, so that physics can be done properly.
00326             /// @details This simply calls: DoMainLoopPhysics, DoMainLoopInputBuffering, DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering, DoMainLoopRender. This is
00327             /// useful for anyone wants to use as little of the existing main loop structure as possible, or does not want to run a certain Items
00328             /// each iteration of the main loop.
00329             void DoMainLoopAllItems(const Real &PreviousFrameTime);
00330 
00331             /// @brief Increments physics by one step
00332             /// @param TimeElapsed This is the amount of time that has elapsed since this function was last called, required for proper physics
00333             /// @details Currently one step is about 1/60 of a second. This function is automatically called in the main loop if a Pre/Post-Physics Callback is
00334             /// set. This is the second step in the main loop chain of events. This is where we expect the majority of our collision events to come
00335             /// from although it is concievable that a game could manually insert those manually. This will not delete events it places
00336             /// in the event manager, that is the responsibility of the code that pulls out the event out.
00337             void DoMainLoopPhysics(const Real &TimeElapsed);
00338 
00339             /// @brief Gathers user input from the OS and places events in the event manager
00340             /// @details This this is automatically called during the mainloop if you have set a Pre/PostInput callback. This will not delete events it places
00341             /// in the event manager, that is the responsibility of the code that pulls out the event out.
00342             void DoMainLoopInputBuffering();
00343 
00344             /// @brief Creates events for each Window manger
00345             /// @details This gather information from system/windows manager events, such as windows  minimization, maximization, program exit, window hidden
00346             /// window shown, and a few other similar types of events. This makes events out of the information and places them in the event manager
00347             /// This will not delete events it places in the event manager, that is the responsibility of the code that pulls out the event out.
00348             void DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering();
00349 
00350             /// @brief This forces the screen to be re-rendered
00351             /// @details This renders the screen based on the status of all in game actors. This is automatically called in the main loop.
00352             void DoMainLoopRender();
00353 
00354         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00355         // Actor Methods
00356         ///////////////////////////////////////
00357             /// @brief The adds and Actor to the physworld.
00358             /// @details This adds, and makes sure that it's physics status and 3d graphics status are
00359             /// properly handled. The phys::World will delete any actor still left in it upon deconstruction.
00360             /// @param ActorToAdd This is a pointer to the actor to be added.
00361             void AddActor(ActorBase* ActorToAdd);
00362 
00363             /// @brief The Removes an Actor from the physworld.
00364             /// @details This removes the actor to the internal graphics and physics systems, and drops the pointer. This does not delete
00365             /// The Actor.
00366             /// @param ActorToRemove This is a pointer to the actor to be removed
00367             void RemoveActor(ActorBase* ActorToRemove);
00368 
00369         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00370         // Physics Methods
00371         ///////////////////////////////////////
00372             /// @brief Sets the gravity.
00373             /// @details Sets the strength and direction of gravity within the world.
00374             /// @param pgrav Vector3 representing the strength and direction of gravity.
00375             void SetGravity(Vector3 pgrav);
00376 
00377             /// @brief Enables and Disables Physics Debug Drawing
00378             /// @details Enables and Disables Physics Debug Drawing using default wireframes. This will force renderings that match the physics
00379             /// subsytem pixel for pixel.
00380             /// @param ToBeEnabled 1 to turn it on, 0 to turn it off. There may be other options in the future, to enable fine tuned control
00381             void SetDebugPhysicsRendering(int ToBeEnabled);
00382 
00383             /// @brief Is Physics Debug Drawing currently enabled?
00384             /// @details lets you check if Physics Debug Drawing is enabled or not.
00385             /// @return 1 for it is on, and 0 for it is not. The may be other options later for selectively cnacking certain features
00386             int GetDebugPhysicsRendering();
00387 
00388             /// @brief How many Wireframes do you want drawn from previous events
00389             /// @details Each frame of the action gets its own wire frame, and how many of those back did you want to see? To see a minimal amount
00390             /// set this to 2, as the first wireframe is commonly entirely inside the  the rendered 3d mesh. You can use World::GetTargetFrameTime()
00391             /// In conjunction with this to specify an amout of seconds worth of wireframes.
00392             /// @param WireFrameCount_ This is a whole number that is the amount of wire frames you wan to see. Don't forget to be mindful of the framerate,
00393             /// Any amount more than just a few seconds worth can be cumbersome.
00394             void SetDebugPhysicsWireCount(Whole WireFrameCount_);
00395 
00396             /// @brief This gets how many WireFrames are being drawn.
00397             /// @details This will tell you how many frames worth of previous in game events are being drawn.
00398             /// @return This returns either 2 or the last amount passed into World::SetDebugPhysicsWireCount .
00399             Whole GetDebugPhysicsWireCount();
00400 
00401         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00402         // Feature Manager Pointers
00403         ///////////////////////////////////////
00404             /// @brief This is a point to the default Call BackManager
00405             /// @details All the callbacks that the main loop and the rest of physgame use are will be found in the callback manager point to by this.
00406             CallBackManager* CallBacks;
00407 
00408             /// @brief This is the default pointer to the Event Manager.
00409             /// @details This is the Event manager that all physworld members will place any events into.
00410             EventManager* Events;
00411 
00412         private:
00413             /// @brief This is a convienient place to keep pointer to our Actors
00414             /// @details Whenever an actor is added, a pointer to it will be stored here.
00415             ActorContainerBase* Actors;
00416     };
